Hello,

I'm currently writing an implementation of NEAT in Ruby. When I'm
f=
inished, I plan to evolve neural nets to control a CYE robot, taking
input =
from a roving eye on the (dynamic) video input from the robot's
video camer=
a, and outputting data about how to move/zoom the roving
eye and how to cha=
nge the robots speed and heading.

However, I can't decide how I will go ab=
out evaluating the networks'
fitnesses. I would think it would be impractic=
al to actually have the
robot run using each neural net from every populati=
on (and it would
involve lots of extra code to manage automatically guiding=
 the robot
back to its charging station when its batteries run low).

Howev=
er, the robot will eventually use the champion network to
actually perform =
a task, so the networks will need to learn how to
process dynamic video dat=
a and respond accordingly. I can't think of a
way to simulate this.

I thou=
ght maybe I would run the robot manually through a number of
ideal courses,=
 recording the video, and compare networks' responses to
the necessary resp=
onses for those courses, but I'm not sure that will
work, as the responses =
during simulation would not affect the video
data. The final net's response=
s will actually move the robot and
therefore affect the video data.

Has an=
yone else tried anything like this, or does anyone have any
ideas about how=
 to evaluate these networks' fitnesses?

Thanks,
Thomas Jack
